validation_test_set.description: 50 test questions for Medical Device RAG system validation

questions.question: What class is a blood glucose monitor?
questions.expected_answer: Class II medical device

questions.question: How are medical devices classified by the FDA?
questions.expected_answer: Three classes based on risk: Class I (low), Class II (moderate), Class III (high)

questions.question: What is the difference between Class I and Class II devices?
questions.expected_answer: Class I: low risk, general controls only; Class II: moderate risk, special controls required

questions.question: What class is a pacemaker?
questions.expected_answer: Class III medical device

questions.question: Are surgical gloves Class I or Class II devices?
questions.expected_answer: Class I medical device

questions.question: What determines if a device needs special controls?
questions.expected_answer: Class II devices require special controls to ensure safety and effectiveness

questions.question: How can I find the classification of my medical device?
questions.expected_answer: Check FDA device database, product codes, or submit classification request

questions.question: What class is an insulin pump?
questions.expected_answer: Class II medical device

questions.question: Can device classification change over time?
questions.expected_answer: Yes, FDA can reclassify devices based on new data or regulatory changes

questions.question: What are general controls for medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: Basic regulatory requirements: registration, listing, labeling, QSR compliance

questions.question: What is a 510(k) submission?
questions.expected_answer: Premarket notification to FDA demonstrating substantial equivalence to predicate device

questions.question: What documents are required for a 510(k) submission?
questions.expected_answer: Device description, intended use, substantial equivalence comparison, performance data, labeling

questions.question: How long does FDA take to review a 510(k)?
questions.expected_answer: FDA has 90 days to review, but may request additional information extending timeline

questions.question: What is substantial equivalence in 510(k) submissions?
questions.expected_answer: Device has same intended use and technological characteristics as legally marketed predicate

questions.question: When is a 510(k) submission required?
questions.expected_answer: For most Class II devices and some Class I devices before marketing

questions.question: What is the difference between Traditional, Special, and Abbreviated 510(k)s?
questions.expected_answer: Traditional: full submission; Special: modifications to own device; Abbreviated: uses guidance/standards

questions.question: Can I market my device before 510(k) clearance?
questions.expected_answer: No, must receive FDA clearance before commercial distribution

questions.question: What is a predicate device?
questions.expected_answer: Legally marketed device used for comparison in substantial equivalence determination

questions.question: What happens if my 510(k) is rejected?
questions.expected_answer: Can address FDA concerns and resubmit, or request supervisory review

questions.question: Do I need clinical data for my 510(k)?
questions.expected_answer: Depends on device and predicate comparison; may need clinical or performance testing

questions.question: What is Software as a Medical Device (SaMD)?
questions.expected_answer: Software intended for medical purposes that can run on general computing platforms

questions.question: How does FDA regulate mobile medical apps?
questions.expected_answer: Based on intended use and risk; low-risk apps may be exempt, others need 510(k) or PMA

questions.question: What is the difference between SaMD and Software in Medical Device (SiMD)?
questions.expected_answer: SaMD is standalone software; SiMD is software that is part of a medical device

questions.question: Are AI/ML algorithms considered medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: Yes, if intended for medical purposes, AI/ML software are regulated as medical devices

questions.question: What documentation is needed for software medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: Software documentation, risk management, validation/verification, cybersecurity information

questions.question: Do fitness apps need FDA approval?
questions.expected_answer: Most fitness apps are low-risk and exempt, unless they diagnose or treat medical conditions

questions.question: What are cybersecurity requirements for medical device software?
questions.expected_answer: Must address cybersecurity risks in design, include security controls, and have update plans

questions.question: How is clinical decision support software regulated?
questions.expected_answer: Depends on level of intervention; high-risk CDS needs FDA review, low-risk may be exempt

questions.question: Can software medical devices be updated after FDA clearance?
questions.expected_answer: Minor updates may not need new submission; major changes require new 510(k) or supplement

questions.question: What standards apply to medical device software?
questions.expected_answer: IEC 62304 for software lifecycle, ISO 14971 for risk management, plus cybersecurity standards

questions.question: What is the Quality System Regulation (QSR)?
questions.expected_answer: FDA regulation (21 CFR 820) establishing quality system requirements for medical device manufacturers

questions.question: What are design controls?
questions.expected_answer: QSR requirements for device design including planning, input, output, review, verification, validation

questions.question: What is CAPA in medical device quality systems?
questions.expected_answer: Corrective and Preventive Action system to identify and eliminate causes of nonconformities

questions.question: What is Medical Device Reporting (MDR)?
questions.expected_answer: Requirement to report device malfunctions, serious injuries, and deaths to FDA

questions.question: What companies need to follow QSR?
questions.expected_answer: Manufacturers of Class II and III devices, and some Class I device manufacturers

questions.question: What is UDI (Unique Device Identification)?
questions.expected_answer: System requiring unique identifiers on medical device labels and packaging for traceability

questions.question: How often should internal audits be conducted?
questions.expected_answer: QSR requires planned intervals based on importance and previous audit results, typically annually

questions.question: What records must be maintained under QSR?
questions.expected_answer: Device master record, device history record, complaint files, and other quality records

questions.question: What is management responsibility under QSR?
questions.expected_answer: Top management must establish quality policy, ensure resource availability, and review system effectiveness

questions.question: When are design controls required?
questions.expected_answer: Required for Class II and III devices, and Class I devices specifically subject to design controls

questions.question: What is biocompatibility testing?
questions.expected_answer: Testing to evaluate biological safety of medical devices in contact with human body

questions.question: When is biocompatibility testing required?
questions.expected_answer: For devices with direct or indirect patient contact, following ISO 10993-1 guidance

questions.question: What is ISO 14971?
questions.expected_answer: International standard for application of risk management to medical devices

questions.question: What electrical safety testing is required for medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: IEC 60601 series standards for medical electrical equipment safety and performance

questions.question: What is sterilization validation?
questions.expected_answer: Process to demonstrate sterilization method effectively eliminates microorganisms

questions.question: Are clinical trials required for all medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: No, depends on device risk and available predicate data; Class III typically requires clinical data

questions.question: What is electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) testing?
questions.expected_answer: Testing to ensure device doesn't interfere with other equipment and isn't affected by interference

questions.question: What is shelf life testing for medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: Testing to determine how long device maintains safety and effectiveness under storage conditions

questions.question: What is usability testing for medical devices?
questions.expected_answer: Human factors testing to ensure safe and effective use by intended users

questions.question: What consensus standards should I consider for my medical device?
questions.expected_answer: Depends on device type; common ones include ISO 13485, ISO 14971, IEC 60601, ISO 10993

metadata.usage_instructions: Run these questions through your RAG system and compare responses to expected answers and key points for validation.

scoring_criteria.correct: Answer contains all key points and aligns with expected answer
scoring_criteria.partial: Answer contains some key points but missing important information
scoring_criteria.incorrect: Answer contradicts expected answer or contains significant errors
